children.text: The student will create works of art that represent personal solutions to art problems.
The student will express ideas and feelings through the creation of works of art.

The student will identify and use
  1. colors—red, blue, yellow, green, orange, violet, brown, black, and white;
  2. textures—sight and touch;
  3. line and line characteristics—straight/curved, thick/thin, long/short, vertical/horizontal, and diagonal;
  4. shape—circle, square, triangle, rectangle, and oval; and
  5. patterns—natural and man-made.
The student will create a work of art that commemorates a personal or historical event.
The student will create a work of art that depicts a specific animal or plant.
The student will create a self-portrait.
The student will identify objects within the environment that occupy space.
The student will identify spatial relationships—left, right, top, bottom, side, center, front, back, over, and under.
The student will describe the sequence of steps in the making of a work of art.
The student will use motor skills (e.g., pinching, pulling, squeezing, twisting, pounding, rolling, folding, cutting, modeling, stamping) to create two-dimensional and three-dimensional works of art.
The student will recognize and discuss various solutions to a single art problem.
The student will use the senses of sight, touch, and hearing as inspirations for works of art.

The student will identify and use
  1. primary colors—red, blue, and yellow;
  2. line and line variations—zigzag, dotted, wavy, and spiral;
  3. texture—visual and tactile;
  4. shape—geometric and organic; and
  5. patterns—alternating and repeating.
The student will create works of art inspired by stories, poems, and themes.
The student will create art from real and imaginary sources of inspiration.
The student will use personal experiences and simulated situations as subject matter in works of art.
The student will demonstrate the ability to recognize size relationships in works of art.
The student will develop eye/hand coordination by drawing and constructing.
The student will observe and depict plants, animals, and people in a landscape work of art.
The student will use motor skills to weave, tear, and otherwise manipulate art materials.
The student will investigate various solutions to a single visual arts problem.
The student will incorporate unanticipated results of art-making into works of art.
The student will use literary sources to generate ideas for works of art.

The student will identify and use
  1. secondary colors—orange, violet, and green;
  2. shapes—geometric and organic;
  3. three-dimensional forms—cube, cylinder, sphere, pyramid, and cone; and
  4. pattern—complex, alternating, and repeating.
The student will use environmental themes and historical events as inspiration for works of art.
The student will create a work of art from observation.
The student will depict objects in proportion within a work of art.
The student will collaborate with others to create a work of art.
The student will identify and use a variety of sources for art ideas, including nature, people, images, imagination, and resource materials.
The student will create a three-dimensional work of art, using a variety of materials.
The student will create a work of art by manipulating clay.
The student will identify innovative solutions used by artists to solve visual problems.
The student will use various art processes and techniques to produce works of art that demonstrate craftsmanship.
The student will develop art ideas from a variety of sources, including print, non-print, and technology.

The student will identify and use
  1. intermediate colors;
  2. warm and cool colors;
  3. positive and negative space;
  4. balance—symmetry and asymmetry;
  5. pattern—extend the sequential structure, using motifs; and
  6. contrast.
The student will compare, contrast, and use organic and geometric shapes in works of art.
The student will create a functional object that reflects the contributions of Greco-Roman civilizations, as found in artifacts.
The student will create the illusion of depth on a two-dimensional surface, using overlapping, size variation, and placement in the picture plane.
The student will identify and use foreground, middle ground, and background in two-dimensional works of art.
The student will identify and use architectural forms (e.g., cube, cylinder, sphere, pyramid, cone).
The student will produce a work of art that communicates feelings.
The student will create a work of art in clay, using the coil-building process.
The student will research and generate ideas for creating works of art, using discussion.
The student will use thumbnail sketches to document thought processes when creating works of art.
The student will create a work of art that uses themes, ideas, and art forms from the past.
The student will identify and use the characteristics of color, including hue, tint, shade, and intensity.
The student will identify and use variety, repetition, and unity in a work of art.
The student will identify and use a variety of lines in a work of art.
The student will describe and use hand-building techniques, including the slab method, to make a ceramic work of art.
The student will identify positive and negative space in works of art.
The student will use contour drawing, perspective drawing, and shading techniques to create a work of art that depicts a three-dimensional object on a two-dimensional surface.
The student will create abstract works of art.
The student will synthesize information to produce works of art.
The student will use the primary colors and black and white to mix a variety of hues, tints, and shades to create a work of art.
The student will use the elements of art—line, shape, form, color, value, texture, and space—to express ideas, images, and emotions.
The student will create repeating patterns, using translation (slide), reflection (flip), and rotation (turn).
The student will use the principles of design, including proportion, rhythm, balance, emphasis, variety, contrast, and unity, to express ideas and create images.
The student will develop ideas for works of art by brainstorming, conducting research, and making preliminary sketches.
The student will collaborate with others to produce a work of art that characterizes a historical time period.
The student will defend a position regarding a historical or contemporary issue through the production of a work of art.
The student will demonstrate an understanding of symbolic meanings by incorporating symbols in a work of art.
The student will use linear perspective in a work of art.
The student will emphasize spatial relationships in works of art.
The student will express ideas through artistic choices of media, techniques, and subject matter.
The student will use technology to produce a work of art.
The student will use three-dimensional art media to create a sculpture in the round, high relief, or bas-relief.
The student will describe the changes that occur in clay, including plastic, leatherhard, greenware, bisque, and glazeware, during the ceramic process.
The student will produce fiber art that reflects the qualities of the fiber art of another age, culture, or country.
The student will solve design problems, using color relationships selected from the color wheel.
The student will use the principles of design, including proportion, rhythm, balance, emphasis, variety, and unity, to express ideas and create images.
The student will use one-point perspective to create the illusion of depth in a two-dimensional drawing.
The student will depict the proportional relationships among the parts of the human body or among other objects.
The student will use visual memory skills to produce a work of art.
The student will use appropriate art media and techniques to create both visual and tactile textures in works of art.
The student will use chiaroscuro to create the illusion of form in a work of art.
The student will produce a kinetic work of art.
The student will utilize fantasy as a means of expression in works of art.
The student will use computer graphics and computer-generated text to create original works of art.
The student will identify and use analogous, complementary, and monochromatic color relationships in works of art.
The student will create the illusion of movement in two-dimensional and three-dimensional works of art.

The student will apply in two-dimensional and three-dimensional works of art the elements of art and the principles of design, including line, shape, form, color, value, texture, space, proportion, rhythm, balance, emphasis, variety, and unity.
The student will use line variations, including directionality, width, and implied line, to create contrasting qualities in a composition.
The student will communicate information and ideas through illustration.

The student will create the illusion of depth in two-dimensional works of art, using a variety of the following devices:
  1. Overlapping;
  2. Atmospheric perspective;
  3. Diminishing size and detail; and
  4. Object placement in the picture plane.
The student will create contour line drawings that demonstrate perceptual skill.
The student will use two-point perspective to create the illusion of depth in a two-dimensional drawing.
The student will create two-dimensional and three-dimensional works of art, integrating the elements of art and principles of design.
The student will create three-dimensional works of art, using geometric forms.
The student will create works of art by representing and interpreting ideas from other fields of knowledge.
The student will use mechanical graphic arts instruments and devices to solve commercial design problems.
The student will use computer design programs to create original works of art.
The student will use problem-solving skills to create a work of art that communicates ideas or emotions.
The student will create works of art that emphasize specific formal color relationships.
The student will further expand and develop the use of the elements of art and the principles of design.
The student will use aerial perspective to create the illusion of depth in a two-dimensional drawing.
The student will use multiple-point perspective to create the illusion of depth in a two-dimensional drawing.
The student will use line to create value in a work of art.
The student will create three-dimensional works of art, using a variety of themes and processes.
The student will identify and analyze the uses of typography in graphic arts.
The student will demonstrate skill in combining text and imagery, using computer technology.
The student will create and maintain an art portfolio.
The student will apply ethical procedures in the execution of works of art.
The student will provide evidence of the critical and artistic processes used to achieve final art solutions in personal works of art by documenting preparation, rough drafts, and final solutions.
The student will identify people who make art as "artists" (e.g., painters, sculptors, printmakers, architects, graphic designers).
The student will identify the purposes for creating works of art.
The student will discuss the concept that people in all cultures create works of art.
The student will describe and discuss similarities and differences between various careers in the visual arts.
The student will recognize and describe how art is an integral part of one's own culture.
The student will identify and describe works of art that communicate feelings, ideas, and information.
The student will identify American cultural symbols and events depicted in art.
The student will recognize the careers related to the media they have studied.
The student will compare the art, artifacts, and architecture of other cultures with that of their own culture.
The student will identify symbols from various cultures.
The student will identify art from other cultures, including Ancient Egypt, Ancient China, and American Indians (First Americans).
The student will identify and discuss common characteristics in various art careers (e.g., painter, sculptor, illustrator, visual art teacher).
The student will discuss how history, culture, and the visual arts influence each other.
The student will identify distinguishing characteristics of landscape, seascape, and cityscape.
The student will compare and contrast architectural styles of ancient cultures, including Greece and Rome.
The student will identify and examine objects of the early West African empire of Mali.
The student will identify how works of art reflect times, places, and cultures.
The student will explain the role of archaeology in learning about the art of past cultures.
The students will identify and discuss a variety of art careers (e.g., potter, weaver, glassmaker, jeweler, local community artist).
The student will compare and contrast abstract and realistic works of art.
The student will recognize, compare, and contrast the characteristics of diverse cultures in contemporary works of art.
The student will identify and describe the influences of ancient cultures on Early American architecture.
The student will examine the roles of crafts and artisans in Colonial Virginia.
The student will investigate artists and their work, using research tools and procedures.
The student will describe and discuss various commercial art careers (e.g., product designer, fashion designer, graphic artist, photographer).
The student will compare contemporary and historical art and architecture.
The student will identify the influences of historic events, subject matter, and media in works of art.
The student will research artists from a variety of cultures and the works of art they have produced.
The student will identify and discuss how American historical events influenced works of art, with emphases on westward expansion and the Civil War.
The student will research, compare, and contrast the art of two cultures, using contemporary technology.
The student will describe and discuss various types of collaborative art careers (e.g., architect, motion picture producer, animator, Web page designer, interior designer).
The student will identify the components of an artist's style, including materials, design, technique, and subject matter.
The student will identify major art movements in American culture from 1877 to the present, with emphasis on relating these movements to changes in science and technology.
The student will identify how artists contribute to society.
The student will compare various art careers and the methods of preparing for them.
The student will identify styles and themes in contemporary and historical works of art.
The student will compare and contrast the characteristics of public art, including monuments.
The student will examine the uses and impact of persuasive techniques in print and electronic media.
The student will identify the roles of artists (e.g., graphic artists, animators, videographers, photographers, advertising artists) in mass media.
The student will identify and analyze art and architecture from various world cultures, periods, or civilizations by styles, symbolism, and technological impact.
The student will describe and place a variety of works in historical and cultural contexts.
The student will compare and contrast works of art according to medium, period, style, and artist.
The student will describe and respond to works of art.
The student will classify objects in the environment by using art vocabulary (e.g., color, texture, line, shape, pattern).
The student will discuss why viewers may have different responses to works of art.
The student will view works of art and describe similarities and differences between them.
The student will describe and discuss the visual qualities and content of works of art, using an art vocabulary.
The student will express opinions with supporting statements regarding works of art.
The student will categorize works of art by subject matter, including portrait, landscape, and still life.
The student will distinguish between natural objects and objects made by man in the environment.
The student will interpret ideas and feelings expressed in personal and others' works of art.
The student will examine and discuss why works of art have been interpreted in different ways throughout history.
The student will describe the problem-solving process involved in producing personal works of art, using appropriate art vocabulary.
The student will discuss the difference between art and other types of objects, using appropriate art vocabulary.
The student will analyze works of art by subject matter, including portrait, landscape, still life, and narrative.
The student will express informed judgments about works of art.

The student will analyze works of art for the use of
  1. rhythm;
  2. balance-symmetry and asymmetry; and
  3. spatial relationships-overlapping, size, proportion, and placement.
The student will interpret works of art for multiple meanings.
The student will analyze works of art based on visual properties.
The student will compare and contrast abstract, representational, and nonrepresentational works of art.
The student will identify and investigate ways that works of art from popular culture reflect the past and influence the present.
The student will identify and investigate ways that works of art from popular culture reflect the past and influence the present.
The student will support the selection of a work of art, using appropriate art vocabulary.
The student will compare and contrast works of art by genre.
The student will compare and contrast art from various cultures and periods, including Pre-Columbian, African-American, Colonial American, and European, using appropriate art vocabulary.
The student will discuss an artist's point of view based on evidence from written sources.
The student will compare and contrast natural and constructed environments.
The student will analyze works of art based on visual properties and historical context.
The student will apply specific criteria to assess a finished product.
The student will discuss the ways that art can be persuasive.
The student will explain how the elements of art, the principles of design, art techniques, and art media influence meaning in works of two-dimensional and three-dimensional art.

The student will demonstrate inquiry skills and appropriate art vocabulary for
  1. describing works of art;
  2. responding to works of art;
  3. interpreting works of art; and
  4. evaluating works of art.
The student will interpret the ideas and emotions expressed in works of art, using appropriate art vocabulary.
The student will identify the relationship between art processes and final solutions.

The student will identify and examine ethical standards in the use of
  1. print and digital images;
  2. materials protected by copyright; and
  3. information technology.
The student will explore and identify subjects, themes, and symbols as they relate to meaning in works of art.
The student will understand the use of personal information, artist intent, cultural influences, and historical context for interpretation of works of art.
The student will identify and apply criteria for judging works of art.
The student will identify and examine ethical and legal considerations in the use of appropriated images and information.
The student will analyze, interpret, and judge works of art based on biographical, historical, or contextual information.
The student will compare and contrast personal experiences with the life experiences depicted in works of art from other cultures.
The student will identify the processes artists use to create works of art, using analysis of rough sketches, drafts, and series.
The student will analyze the effect the elements of art and the principles of design have on the communication of ideas.
The student will investigate and discuss the use of social, cultural, and historical context as they contribute to meaning in a work of art.
The student will communicate how personal experiences influence critical judgments about and interpretations of works of art.
The student will critique in oral and written form, personal work and the work of others, using appropriate art vocabulary.
The student will discuss and explain ideas and expressions in personal works of art.
The student will select a preferred work of art from among others and explain why it was chosen.
The student will discuss thoughts, experiences, and feelings expressed in works of art.
The student will discuss the reasons why works of art have value.
The student will express a point of view regarding what art is and what purpose art serves.
The student will describe and discuss ideas and emotions communicated in works of art.
The student will discuss local public art and its value to the community.
The student will describe the meanings and feelings evoked by works of art.
The student will discuss the ways that the art of a culture reflects its people's attitudes and beliefs.
The student will examine the relationship between form and function in the artifacts of a culture.
The student will identify common attributes in works of art produced by artists within one culture.
The student will determine why art has value.
The student will develop and describe personal reasons for valuing works of art.
The student will discuss how criteria used to value art may vary from one culture to another.
The student will discuss how personal beliefs influence responses to works of art.
The student will formulate questions about works of art.
The student will select a preferred work of art from among others and defend the choice, using appropriate art vocabulary.
The student will discuss the role of art and artists in society.
The student will discuss how criteria used to value art within a culture vary over time.
The student will describe a valued object within present-day culture in terms of aesthetic preferences.
The student will articulate reasons for establishing preferences among works of art, using appropriate art vocabulary.
The student will respond to works of art and analyze those responses in terms of cultural and visual meaning.
The student will generate philosophical questions regarding meanings in works of art.
The student will describe the manner in which the belief systems of a viewer may influence contemplation of works of art.
The student will explain orally and in writing the means by which visual art evokes sensory and emotional responses.
The student will analyze and describe how factors of time and place influence visual characteristics that give meaning and value to a work of art.
The student will generate questions about the nature of art and possible answers to the questions.
The student will describe ways that social and cultural beliefs can influence responses to works of art.
The student will describe personal responses to the visual qualities of a work of art.
The student will investigate the purposes of art.
The student will discuss and analyze the purposes, values, and meanings of works of art.
The student will formulate and respond to meaningful questions about works of art, based on observations and interpretations.
The student will describe personal sensory responses to the visual qualities of a work of art, using appropriate art vocabulary.
Visual Communication and Production
The student will maintain a sketchbook/journal of ideas and writings to use as a resource and planning tool.
The student will select representative works of art for a portfolio.
The student will produce works of art that demonstrate the experimental application of the elements of art and the principles of design.
The student will recognize and identify technological developments in the visual arts.
The student will demonstrate the use of technology and electronic media as artistic tools.
The student will produce works of art that demonstrate an understanding of two-dimensional and three-dimensional art media, with emphases on drawing, painting, and sculpture.
The student will use a variety of subject matter and symbols to express ideas in works of art.
The student will create works of art that represent originality, personal expression, and craftsmanship.
The student will define and practice ethical procedures when producing works of art.
The student will demonstrate skill in preparing and displaying works of art.
Cultural Context and Art History
The student will describe and discuss various art-related careers (e.g., art historian, art critic, museum educator, curator, art educator).
The student will describe connections among media, elements of art, principles of design, themes, and concepts found in historical and contemporary art.
The student will describe works of art, using appropriate art vocabulary.
The student will identify major art movements and influential artists according to locations, cultures, and historical periods.
The student will identify features of a work of art, including media, subject matter, and formal choices, that influence meaning.
The student will describe the role of mass media in influencing preference, perception, and communication.
The student will describe and analyze the function, purpose, and perceived meanings of specific works of art studied.
The student will identify and examine symbols in works of art and discuss possible reasons for their use.
Judgment and Criticism
The student will employ critical evaluation skills and use appropriate art vocabulary when evaluating and interpreting works of art.
The student will critique works of art with reference to the elements of art and the principles of design.
The student will analyze an original work of art by describing, responding, analyzing, interpreting, and judging or evaluating.
The student will differentiate between personal preference and informed judgment when discussing works of art.
The student will use established criteria to participate in critiques.
The student will describe criteria affecting quality in a work of art, including concept, composition, technical skills, realization of perceived intentions, and the work of art as a whole.
The student will classify works of art as representational, abstract, nonobjective, and/or conceptual.
Aesthetics
The student will discuss how aesthetics are reflected in everyday life.
The student will discuss ways that aesthetic responses to works of art differ from judgments.
The student will demonstrate in writing the ability to support personal criteria for making visual aesthetic judgments.
The student will discuss current problems and issues of the art world.
The student will study and describe the aesthetic properties found in works of art.
The student will speculate on the intentions and choices of those who created a work of art.
The student will discuss art from a variety of aesthetic stances, including formalism, expressionism, contextualism, and imitationalism.
Visual Communication and Production
The student will expand the use of a sketchbook/journal by adding preliminary sketches, finished drawings, critical writings, and class notes.
The student will demonstrate the ability to evaluate and select works of art for an expanded portfolio.
The student will demonstrate effective use of the elements of art and the principles of design in a variety of art media.
The student will use technology to create and manipulate images.
The student will demonstrate proficiency and craftsmanship in the use of an expanded range of art media.
The student will use historical subject matter and symbols as inspiration to produce works of art.
The student will employ the visual problem-solving process in the production of original works of art.
The student will adhere to ethical procedures when producing works of art.
The student will select and prepare two-dimensional and three-dimensional works of art for display.
The student will identify characteristics of works of art that are presented as a series or sequence.
Cultural Context and Art History
The student will identify artists and visual arts resources within the community.
The student will demonstrate an understanding of an art career, using oral or written communication.
The student will identify works of art and artistic developments that relate to historical time periods and locations.
The student will discuss or write about art history, using an expanded art vocabulary.
The student will identify and examine works of art in their historical context and relate them to historical events.
The student will describe distinguishing features in works of art that may be used to differentiate among a variety of historical periods and cultural contexts.
The student will examine and discuss societal conditions that influence works of art.
The student will identify the function and interpret the meaning of a work of art or an artifact in its original context.
The student will describe symbols present in works of art in relation to historical meaning.
Judgment and Criticism
The student will describe, analyze, interpret, and judge works of art, using an expanded art vocabulary.
The student will use an expanded art vocabulary to assess the effectiveness of the communication of ideas in personal works of art.
The student will demonstrate orally and in writing, the ability to interpret and compare historical references found in original works of art.
The student will identify and analyze characteristics of works of art that represent a variety of styles.
The student will participate in class critiques and criticisms based on one or more established models (e.g., Feldman, Broudy, Barrett).
The student will describe how the perception of quality in works of art has changed over time.
Aesthetics
The student will examine, compare, and contrast aesthetic ideals throughout history.
The student will discuss how responses to the natural environment differ from responses to a man-made or a constructed environment.
The student will demonstrate the ability to reflect on and analyze personal responses to works of art and artifacts.
The student will support opinions by reasoned processes, using an expanded art vocabulary.
The student will describe, refine, and organize personal ideas about the aesthetic qualities of a work of art.
The student will research and investigate the intentions of those who created specific works of art.
The student will investigate and demonstrate the fact that art can be viewed from a variety of aesthetic stances.
Visual Communication and Production
The student will maintain a sketchbook/journal that demonstrates research, fluency of ideas, concepts, media, and processes.

The student will maintain a portfolio that demonstrates the ability to select work objectively, based on technical skill, personal style, direction, and intended purpose by
  1. developing an area of concentration; and
  2. editing and updating the portfolio to take to Art IV.
The student will produce works of art that integrate a consistent knowledge of the elements of art and the principles of design.
The student will use technology to create works of art that integrate electronic and traditional media.
The student will develop a series or sequence of related works of art.
The student will develop skill, confidence, and craftsmanship in the use of media, techniques, and processes to achieve desired intentions in works of art.
The student will use knowledge of art styles, movements, and cultures as inspiration to produce works of art.
The student will demonstrate initiative, originality, fluency, commitment to tasks, and openness to new ideas in the creation of works of art.
The student will maintain a high-level of integrity in ethical procedures when producing works of art.

The student will present and display works of art as part of the artistic process by
  1. selecting works of art for display;
  2. preparing for display;
  3. presenting the exhibition; and
  4. participating in a group assessment of the exhibition.
Cultural Context and Art History
The student will analyze a selected career opportunity in art, identifying the training, skills, and plan of action necessary for realizing such a professional art goal.
The student will research and analyze personally influential artists, art styles, and cultures that have contributed to the student's developing portfolio.
The student will compare and analyze relationships between styles or cultures, using an expanded art vocabulary.
The student will identify the distinguishing features that place a work of art within a particular style, region, or period.
The student will analyze and discuss the influences of one culture upon another.
The student will describe the relationship between form and function as it relates to culture and style.
The student will categorize works of art by styles and cultures.
Judgment and Criticism
The student will use an expanded art vocabulary related to design, composition, aesthetic concepts, and art criticism when discussing works of art.
The student will write a critique of a work of art, assuming the point of view of one of the following aesthetic stances: formalist, imitationalist, expressionist, or contextualist.
The student will compare and defend two or more points of view regarding a work of art.
The student will participate in developing criteria for a class critique.
The student will analyze the attributes of a work of art in terms of its ability to evoke a viewer response and command sustained attention.
Aesthetics
The student will analyze the changes in aesthetic sensibilities that result from the influence of one culture upon another.
The student will research, compare, and contrast the aesthetic ideals of two or more artists.
The student will demonstrate in writing the ability to identify, analyze, and apply criteria for making visual aesthetic judgments.
The student will debate the perceived intentions of those creating works of art.
The student will study, describe, analyze, and interpret the aesthetic qualities of works of art.
The student will defend multiple points of view regarding works of art.
The student will describe the effects that works of art have on groups, individuals, and cultures.
Visual Communication and Production
The student will maintain a self-directed sketchbook/journal demonstrating independent research directly related to studio work.

The student will demonstrate mastery through a culminating portfolio that exhibits quality, concentration, breadth of experience, technical skill, and development over time in the following areas:
  1. Works of art that exhibit an understanding of human proportion, composition, and spatial relationships;
  2. A comprehensive concentration that exhibits in-depth grasp of composition, technical skill, and personal style; and
  3. Examples of two-dimensional and three-dimensional works extensive enough to show a knowledge of space, form, and function throughout the portfolio.
The student will demonstrate an advanced level of knowledge of the elements of art and the principles of design in works of art.
The student will select and use appropriate technology and electronic media for personal expressive works of art.
The student will demonstrate confidence, sensitivity, and advanced skill in applying media, techniques, processes, and craftsmanship to achieve desired intentions in works of art.
The student will select among a range of subject matter, symbols, meaningful images, and media to communicate personal expression.
The student will use experimental techniques to reflect a personal, creative, and original problem-solving approach.
The student will demonstrate personal responsibility and integrity in ethical matters and procedures, including adherence to copyright laws, when producing works of art.

The student will present and display works of art as part of the artistic process by
  1. selecting works of art for display;
  2. preparing for display;
  3. publicizing the exhibition;
  4. presenting the exhibition; and
  5. completing a self-evaluation of the exhibition.
The student will refine a series or sequence of related works.
Cultural Context and Art History
The student will evaluate careers in the visual arts in relation to personal skills, artistic aptitudes, and interests.
The student will select, research, and analyze artists and works of art related to areas of concentration in art that are of personal interest.
The student will use an extensive, high-level art vocabulary to analyze, evaluate, and interpret works of selected artists.
The student will describe where, when, and by whom specific works of art were created.
The student will compare and analyze perceived relationships between the features in works of selected artists and personal works of art.
The student will identify the influences of selected artists on society and culture.
The student will justify personal choices and the influences from art history that are reflected in personal works of art.
The student will discuss how the function and intended meaning of personal work is a reflection of contemporary culture.
The student will develop personal symbols and incorporate them in works of art.
Judgment and Criticism
The student will use an extensive, high-level art vocabulary related to design, composition, aesthetic concepts, and art criticism when discussing works of art.
The student will compare and contrast two opposing written reviews of the same exhibition and prepare to discuss a personal point of view based on what he or she has read.
The student will write a personal critique of a current art exhibition.
The student will identify, analyze, and apply a variety of criteria for making visual judgments.
The student will demonstrate the ability to conduct an effective critique.
The student will critically view the quality and expressive form of works of art as a source of inspiration and insight and as a potential contribution to personal works of art.
Aesthetics
The student will explain how experiences and values affect aesthetic responses to works of art.
The student will discuss in writing the application of criteria for making visual aesthetic judgments of personal works of art.
The student will analyze and discuss relationships between works of art in terms of opposing aesthetic views.
The student will study, analyze, interpret, and relate the aesthetic qualities of the art works of others to personal work.
The student will justify personal perceptions of an artist's intent, using visual clues and research.
The student will discuss in writing the impact of contemporary art on the development of a personal style.
